---

Perfect! I have successfully fixed the SQLAlchemy relationship warnings in your Flask application. Here's what I did:

## Problem
Your Flask application was showing SQLAlchemy warnings about overlapping relationships between the `User` and `Follow` models:

```
SAWarning: relationship 'User.following' will copy column users.id to column follows.follower_id, which conflicts with relationship(s): 'Follow.follower'
SAWarning: relationship 'User.followers' will copy column users.id to column follows.following_id, which conflicts with relationship(s): 'Follow.following'
```

## Solution
I added the `overlaps` parameter to the relationship definitions in the `User` model in `backend/models.py`:

```python
following = db.relationship(
    'Follow',
    foreign_keys=[Follow.follower_id],
    lazy='dynamic',
    cascade='all, delete-orphan',
    overlaps="follower"  # Added this parameter
)
followers = db.relationship(
    'Follow',
    foreign_keys=[Follow.following_id],
    lazy='dynamic',
    cascade='all, delete-orphan',
    overlaps="following"  # Added this parameter
)
```

## Result
✅ The SQLAlchemy warnings have been eliminated  
✅ The models can be imported without any warnings  
✅ The application functionality remains intact  
✅ No linting errors were introduced  

The `overlaps` parameter tells SQLAlchemy that these relationships are intentionally overlapping and should not generate warnings. This is the recommended approach for handling many-to-many relationships with an association table like your `Follow` model.

Your Flask application should now run without those annoying SQLAlchemy warnings while maintaining all the existing functionality for user following/unfollowing features.

---
